title: Vintage Eyewear Styles
description: From cat-eye frames to aviator sunglasses, how well do you remember the iconic eyewear of decades past?

questions.question: What women's eyeglass frame style, featuring upswept corners that resembled a feline, was the most popular frame of the 1950s?
questions.explanation: Cat-eye glasses, with their distinctive upswept corners often embellished with rhinestones, were the defining eyewear style for women throughout the 1950s.

questions.question: Which type of sunglasses, originally designed for military pilots in the 1930s, became a fashion icon by the 1960s?
questions.explanation: Aviator sunglasses, designed by Bausch & Lomb for U.S. Army Air Corps pilots, became fashionable for civilians by the 1960s and an enduring style icon.

questions.question: Which Ray-Ban sunglasses style, featuring a distinctive trapezoidal frame, became iconic after appearing in many 1950s and 1960s films?
questions.explanation: Ray-Ban Wayfarers, introduced in 1956, became one of the best-selling sunglasses in history, worn by stars like Audrey Hepburn and James Dean.

questions.question: What thick, dark-framed men's eyeglasses style, popular in the 1950s and 1960s, was notably worn by Buddy Holly?
questions.explanation: Horn-rimmed glasses, with their thick dark frames, were a distinctive 1950s men's style. Buddy Holly made them an iconic rock and roll accessory.

questions.question: What style of glasses features a bold upper frame and a thin wire lower rim, popular for men in the 1950s and 1960s?
questions.explanation: Browline glasses, with a bold plastic upper frame (resembling eyebrows) and a thin metal lower rim, were the most popular glasses style of the 1950s and early 1960s.

questions.question: What oversized, round sunglasses style became a signature look for Jackie Kennedy Onassis in the 1960s and 1970s?
questions.explanation: Jackie Kennedy Onassis was famous for wearing oversized round sunglasses, which became known as 'Jackie O sunglasses' and remain a classic style.

questions.question: What type of small, round wire-rimmed glasses became associated with John Lennon and the hippie movement in the late 1960s?
questions.explanation: Small round wire-rimmed glasses, nicknamed 'granny glasses,' became a counterculture fashion statement in the late 1960s, famously worn by John Lennon.

questions.question: What decorative addition to 1950s women's cat-eye glasses made them sparkle and catch the light?
questions.explanation: Rhinestones embedded in the corners and along the brow line of cat-eye frames added glamorous sparkle to 1950s women's glasses.

questions.question: Which large, colorful eyeglass frame style became fashionable for women in the 1970s and 1980s?
questions.explanation: Oversized eyeglass frames in bold colors and shapes dominated women's eyewear in the 1970s and 1980s, with frames covering much of the face.

questions.question: What eyeglass chain, attached to the temple tips and worn around the neck, was a practical 1960s accessory for women?
questions.explanation: Eyeglass chains (or leashes), often made of beaded or decorative links, were worn around the neck so women could remove their glasses without losing them.

questions.question: What innovation in eyeglass lenses, introduced widely in the 1970s, allowed one pair to work for both near and far vision without visible lines?
questions.explanation: Progressive lenses (no-line bifocals) became widely available in the 1970s, offering a gradual transition between prescriptions without the visible line of traditional bifocals.

questions.question: What type of sunglasses with color-changing lenses that darkened in sunlight became popular in the 1960s and 1970s?
questions.explanation: Photochromic lenses, which automatically darkened in sunlight and lightened indoors, were introduced by Corning in 1966 and became popular through the 1970s.

questions.question: Which Tom Cruise movie in 1986 caused a massive surge in sales of Ray-Ban Aviator sunglasses?
questions.explanation: Tom Cruise wearing Ray-Ban Aviators in 'Top Gun' (1986) caused Aviator sales to increase by 40%, making them the must-have sunglasses of the decade.

questions.question: What novelty item, consisting of glasses with a fake nose and mustache attached, was a popular gag gift in the 1960s and 1970s?
questions.explanation: Groucho glasses (also called nose glasses), inspired by Groucho Marx, were a classic novelty item found in joke shops and party stores for decades.

questions.question: What 1983 Tom Cruise movie helped revive sales of Ray-Ban Wayfarer sunglasses from near-discontinuation?
questions.explanation: Tom Cruise wearing Ray-Ban Wayfarers in 'Risky Business' (1983) saved the style from being discontinued, boosting sales from 18,000 to 360,000 pairs per year.
